elements.content: Five new metal pyrazine complex templated Anderson−Evans cluster based solids, (Hpyz)[{Co(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (7), (Hpyz)[{Zn(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (8), [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2·6H2O (9) (pyz = pyrazine), [Na(CrMo6(OH)8O16)]·10H2O (10), and (Hpyz)[{Ni(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (11) were crystallized from aqueous solution by reacting sodium molybdate, chromium chloride, metal chloride, and pyrazine at room temperature. The crystal structure, phase purity, and thermal stability of the crystals were established by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, FTIR, TGA, and magnetic measurements. 7, 8, and 11 are isostructural and show covalently linked 1D anionic chains of alternating Anderson−Evans cluster and cationic complex, {M(pyz)2(H2O)2O2/2} (M = Co, Ni, and Zn); free protonated pyrazinium moieties provide additional counter-charge and further stability through nonbonding interactions. 9 is a rare example of a 1D coordination polymer of the composition {Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2+ that supramolecularly aggregates with two counter anions, the discrete molybdate cluster and acetate, along with water molecules. 10 is a new pseudopolymorph of a sodium based chromium molybdate cluster exhibiting 2D layers; the sheets are held together by corrugated water sheets made of decameric water clusters. This paper discusses how weak interactions between aggregating tectons induce different supramolecular assemblies that eventually result in the nucleation of a crystal. The retrosynthetic analysis proposed here provides molecular insights to interpret the crystal engineering of these complex solids and directions for designing new solids in the system.

elements.content: Polyoxomolybdates (POM) are versatile inorganic materials built of nanosize building blocks of oxomolybdate units containing a few molybdenum atoms to several hundred, as in giant clusters. Some of these clusters are also stabilized in the presence of heteroatoms such as B, P, Si, etc. Synthesis of POM anion based solids from aqueous solution under ambient or hydrothermal conditions has been the subject of study by several groups to obtain functional materials that are relevant in the areas of catalysis, electronics, magnetism, sensors, etc. In recent years, in situ formation of a metal complex has been exploited to assemble diverse transition metal molybdates from discrete cluster based (zero-dimensional) to covalently linked 1D chains, 2D sheets, or 3D frameworks. Synthesis of POM based solids is mostly achieved through a crystallization process from solution; however a rational approach lacks understanding of the nucleation of a crystal in terms of supramolecular aggregation. Influence of the chemical (pH, concentration, etc.) and external (temperature, pressure, solvent) variables in favoring a particular molybdate cluster and the resulting architecture is rarely attempted.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxomolybdates (POM) are versatile inorganic materials built of nanosize building blocks of oxomolybdate units containing a few molybdenum atoms to several hundred, as in giant clusters. Some of these clusters are also stabilized in the presence of heteroatoms such as B, P, Si, etc. Synthesis of POM anion based solids from aqueous solution under ambient or hydrothermal conditions has been the subject of study by several groups to obtain functional materials that are relevant in the areas of catalysis, electronics, magnetism, sensors, etc. In recent years, in situ formation of a metal complex has been exploited to assemble diverse transition metal molybdates from discrete cluster based (zero-dimensional) to covalently linked 1D chains, 2D sheets, or 3D frameworks. Synthesis of POM based solids is mostly achieved through a crystallization process from solution; however a rational approach lacks understanding of the nucleation of a crystal in terms of supramolecular aggregation. Influence of the chemical (pH, concentration, etc.) and external (temperature, pressure, solvent) variables in favoring a particular molybdate cluster and the resulting architecture is rarely attempted.

elements.content: A few years ago, we provoked the question, “How molecules turn into solids?”, and since then, we have been investigating the crystallization of organic, inorganic, and metal organic solids from aqueous solution by adopting a structure−synthesis correlation. One of our objectives is to rationalize the synthetic protocol by establishing a link between molecules aggregating in the solution and the supramolecular assembly observed in the solid state. Since no reliable kinetic and thermodynamic data are available for the crystallization of these complex solids from solution, we have developed a retrosynthetic approach for interpreting the crystal packing. Lehn’s definition of supramolecular reaction, “the chemistry beyond molecule”, the concept of Desiraju’s supramolecular synthon, Wuest’s tecton, and Etter’s principles of H-bonding are all integrated in our approach. Crystallization is a supramolecular reaction mediated in a solvent between tectons that may also include solvent molecules. On the basis of the solids known to crystallize from a system, it is possible to propose reaction pathways in terms of molecular recognition and supramolecular aggregation between tectons. Tectons can be metal complexes with ligands such as water, chloride, sulfate, organic ligands (e.g., N-containing organic base) in a particular geometry, POM cluster, solvent molecules, etc. We demonstrated our analysis to interpret the crystal packing of several copper based nonmolecular solids that include salts, minerals, MOFs, and MCPs. The model is based on pattern recognition and provides an elegant description of the architecture of a crystal by addressing the influence of the geometry, functionality, and reactivity of copper tecton(s) in directing a specific supramolecular assembly. The method accounts for the occurrence of solids with the same composition, but different atomic arrangements (polymorphs and supramolecular isomers) and varying composition with different metal−ligand ratio and degree of hydration (anhydrous to hydrated). It also gives a chemically viable explanation for the coexistence of covalent and noncovalent interactions noticeable in the solid state. Clustering of water molecules, different clusters as in POM, acid−base chemistry, and redox reactions between interacting molecules, and coordination polymerization can all be justified on a molecular basis. Self-assembly between aggregating molecules demonstrates the influence of weak forces on different length scales, making the dimensionality of the solid state structures perceptible.

elements.content: Our group has been involved in the crystallization of POM based solids in the presence of isomeric azoles and azines and transition metal. Initially, we carried out the reaction at room temperature, as increasing temperature (hydrothermal between 50 and 200 °C) produced more stable octamolybdate based solids; also, higher temperature favors reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) and of molybdenum(VI) to lower valent molybdenum (V or IV). Our earlier works with azoles and azines led to several interesting molybdate frameworks wherein the in situ metal complex derivatizes or links POM clusters. Among the POM anions, a hetero-polyoxomolybdate of the composition [H m XMo6O24] n−, popularly known as an Anderson−Evans cluster, was found to be a dominant building block in several solids. The anionic cluster is stabilized in the presence of ten different metal ions; the cluster occurs as a discrete counter anion or covalently linked to other metal ions or complexes ( of the Supporting Information). This molybdate cluster based solid also shows promising catalytic activity. We chose the chromium analogue as a tecton due to its almost planar geometry, high solubility, and reasonable stability in aqueous solution under ambient conditions and its lack of reactivity with azoles or azines. The choice of chromium in the reaction medium facilitated the exclusion of other competitive molybdate clusters. In a recent paper, we examined the supramolecular reactivity of a copper pyrazole complex with chromium based Anderson−Evans clusters (). In the present work, we chose pyrazine for three reasons: pyrazine is known to form complexes as well as coordination polymers (CPs), unlike pyrazole, with divalent transition metal ions (see Table S1). It interacts with molybdates only under hydrothermal conditions. Pyrazine, being a very weak base (pK a 1 and pK a 2, respectively, are 0.6 and −5.8), makes protonation possible only in very acidic media. Our objective was to explore the supramolecular reactivity in the system chromium molybdate cluster−metal ions−pyrazine and crystallize metal coordination polymers (MCPs) incorporated with Anderson−Evans clusters. The four divalent metal chlorides (Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) have been reported to form CPs with pyrazine. Of these, copper and zinc formed 1D CPs of the composition M(pyz)Cl2 (M = Cu, Zn) while cobalt formed a 2D coordination polymer, Co(pyz)2Cl2. The formation of a nickel based pyrazine chloride is reported, but its crystal structure is not known. The metals also formed CPs with pyrazine in the presence of other reactants (). There is only one example in which an Anderson cluster is incorporated with a cadmium CP (see ). In this paper, we describe our efforts to synthesize new crystals based on Anderson−Evans type POM with different transition metal ions [(Co in 7), (Zn in 8), (Ni in 9 and 11)] and (Na in 10) in the presence of pyrazine. This paper provides chemical insights into the crystallization of these solids and rationalizes the occurrence and absence of other phases in terms of a retrosynthesis. The proposed pathways project future directions for the synthesis of new solids.

elements.content: Initially two different aqueous solutions were prepared. The experimental conditions were optimized to enable homogeneity of the solution before and after mixing. Solution A was prepared by adding Na2MoO4·2H2O (2.35 mmol, Merck, 99%) to the solution of CrCl3·6H2O (1.57 mmol, CDH, 99%) in 15 mL of water; this was further acidified with 5 mL of glacial acetic acid. Solution B was prepared by mixing pyrazine (2.52 mmol, Merck, 99%) with the solution of MCl2·xH2O (1.68 mmol, Merck, 99%) (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) in 10 mL of water and 10 mL of methanol. Solution A was then added to solution B with stirring. The resulting clear dark green colored solution was left for crystallization at room temperature. Red block crystals of 7 were obtained after 6 weeks approximately in about 75% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 7: C, 10.35; H, 1.65; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.62; H, 1.74; N, 6.11. Pink block crystals of 8 were obtained after 8 weeks approximately in about 71% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 8: C, 10.30; H, 1.64; N, 6.01. Found: C, 10.41; H, 1.72; N, 6.11. Blue block crystals of 9 were obtained after 4 weeks approximately in about 78% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 9: C, 8.64; H, 2.88; N, 3.36. Found: C, 8.78; H, 2.86; N, 3.69. When M = Cu, as soon as solution A was added to solution B, immediate precipitation occurred. Green precipitate was filtered, washed with acetone, and dried. The remaining filterate was left for crystallization at room temperature. Pink block crystals of 10 were obtained after 12 weeks approximately in about 81% yield (based on Mo).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Initially two different aqueous solutions were prepared. The experimental conditions were optimized to enable homogeneity of the solution before and after mixing. Solution A was prepared by adding Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (2.35 mmol, Merck, 99%) to the solution of CrCl3⋅6H2O (1.57 mmol, CDH, 99%) in 15 mL of water; this was further acidified with 5 mL of glacial acetic acid. Solution B was prepared by mixing pyrazine (2.52 mmol, Merck, 99%) with the solution of MCl2⋅xH2O (1.68 mmol, Merck, 99%) (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) in 10 mL of water and 10 mL of methanol. Solution A was then added to solution B with stirring. The resulting clear dark green colored solution was left for crystallization at room temperature. Red block crystals of 7 were obtained after 6 weeks approximately in about 75% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 7: C, 10.35; H, 1.65; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.62; H, 1.74; N, 6.11. Pink block crystals of 8 were obtained after 8 weeks approximately in about 71% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 8: C, 10.30; H, 1.64; N, 6.01. Found: C, 10.41; H, 1.72; N, 6.11. Blue block crystals of 9 were obtained after 4 weeks approximately in about 78% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 9: C, 8.64; H, 2.88; N, 3.36. Found: C, 8.78; H, 2.86; N, 3.69. When M = Cu, as soon as solution A was added to solution B, immediate precipitation occurred. Green precipitate was filtered, washed with acetone, and dried. The remaining filterate was left for crystallization at room temperature. Pink block crystals of 10 were obtained after 12 weeks approximately in about 81% yield (based on Mo).

elements.content: We also carried out a blank reaction by evaporating solution A without the addition of solution B. Dark green blocklike crystals of 1 were obtained after one month in about 54% yield (based on Mo). The crystals of 1 were filtered, and the supernatant liquid was allowed to evaporate at room temperature; pink blocklike crystals of 2 were obtained after 2 weeks in about 32% yield (based on Mo). In the same way, a blank reaction was carried out on solution B; in all four cases (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn), only powder (3−6) was obtained. When the metal to ligand ratio was increased to 1:3, blue crystals of 11 were obtained after 5 weeks in about 73% yield (based on Mo) in the presence of nickel. Elem. Anal. Calcd for 11: C, 10.36; H, 1.51; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.31; H, 1.48; N, 6.01. In the presence of cobalt and zinc, 7 and 8 were crystallized after 4 and 3 weeks, respectively.

In the same way, a blank reaction was carried out on solution B; in all four cases (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn), only powder (3-6) was obtained. When the metal to ligand ratio was increased to 1:3, blue crystals of 11 were obtained after 5 weeks in about 73% yield (based on Mo) in the presence of nickel. Elem. Anal. Calcd for 11: C, 10.36; H, 1.51; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.31; H, 1.48; N, 6.01. In the presence of cobalt and zinc, 7 and 8 were crystallized after 4 and 3 weeks, respectively.

elements.content:
Scheme shows the experimental procedure involved in the crystallization of 7−11.

X-ray Structure Determination

X-ray diffraction studies of crystal mounted on a capillary were carried out on a BRUKER AXS SMART-APEX diffractometer with a CCD area detector (Kα = 0.71073 Å; monochromator = graphite). Frames were collected at T = 293 K by ω-, ϕ-, and 2θ-rotation at 10 s per frame with SAINT. The measured intensities were reduced to F 2 and corrected for absorption with SADABS. Structure solution, refinement, and data output were carried out with the SHELXTL program. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. C−H hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions by using a riding model. O−H hydrogen atoms were localized by difference Fourier maps and refined in subsequent refinement cycles. Images were created with the Diamond program. Hydrogen bonding interactions in the crystal lattice were calculated with SHELXTL and Diamond. Crystal and refinement data are summarized in Table .

Images were created with the Diamond program. Hydrogen bonding interactions in the crystal lattice were calculated with SHELXTL and Diamond. Crystal and refinement data are summarized in Table .

FTIR was recorded on a Nicolet 5DX spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. TG analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 and DTA7 system on well ground samples in a flowing nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were determined on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 series II C, H, N analyzer. Room-temperature powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. Data were collected with a step size of 0.05° and at count time of 1 s per step over the range 2° < 2θ < 60°. The susceptibility measurements as a function of temperature were performed with a SQUID magnetometer of Quantum Design Inc., USA. Diamagnetic corrections were estimated from Pascal’s constants. Rietveld powder diffraction analysis of all the powders was carried out using Topas 4-2, Bruker, for ensuring homogeneity of the synthesized products.

Other Physical Measurements

FTIR was recorded on a Nicolet 5DX spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets. TG analysis was carried out using a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 and DTA7 system on well ground samples in a flowing nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were determined on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 series II C, H, N analyzer. Room-temperature powder X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. Data were collected with a step size of 0.05° and at count time of 1 s per step over the range 2° < 2θ < 60°. The susceptibility measurements as a function of temperature were performed with a SQUID magnetometer of Quantum Design Inc., USA. Diamagnetic corrections were estimated from Pascal's constants. Rietveld powder diffraction analysis of all the powders was carried out using Topas 4-2, Bruker, for ensuring homogeneity of the synthesized products.

elements.content: Initially we attempted crystallization from solutions A and B independently to identify the dominant molecules that trigger a phase transition. Crystallization from solution A led to the solid [{Cr3(O)(CH3COO)6(H2O)3}2{CrMo6(OH)7O17}]·24H2O (1) (). After the isolation of 1, another solid [Na{Na(H2O)3}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (2) crystallized out of the supernatant solution (). 1 and 2 were found to be the same compounds reported in the literature as well as by us. When crystallization was attempted from metal pyrazine solution (B), we invariably obtained only polycrystalline samples. Under our reaction conditions, no suitable single crystals could be grown. Hence, we did the preliminary structural analysis using powder X-ray diffraction and Rietveld refinement (). While the copper pyrazine solid precipitated instantaneously (within a few minutes), in other cases precipitation occurred only after a few days. Cobalt (3) and nickel (4) yielded isostructural 2D CPs of the composition [M(pyz)2Cl2] while copper (5) and zinc (6) formed isostructural 1D CPs [M(pyz)Cl2]. Rietveld analysis of powder XRD suggested that 4 is isostructural to the cobalt analogue 3 ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystallization of Metal Pyrazine Complex or Coordination Polymer Based on an Anderson-Evans Type Cluster

Initially we attempted crystallization from solutions A and B independently to identify the dominant molecules that trigger a phase transition. Crystallization from solution A led to the solid [{Cr3(O)(CH3COO)6(H2O)3}2{CrMo6(OH)7O17}]⋅24H2O (1) (). After the isolation of 1, another solid [Na{Na(H2O)3}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O (2) crystallized out of the supernatant solution (). 1 and 2 were found to be the same compounds reported in the literature as well as by us. When crystallization was attempted from metal pyrazine solution (B), we invariably obtained only polycrystalline samples. Under our reaction conditions, no suitable single crystals could be grown. Hence, we did the preliminary structural analysis using powder X-ray diffraction and Rietveld refinement (). While the copper pyrazine solid precipitated instantaneously (within a few minutes), in other cases precipitation occurred only after a few days. Cobalt (3) and nickel (4) yielded isostructural 2D CPs of the composition [M(pyz)2Cl2] while copper (5) and zinc (6) formed isostructural 1D CPs [M(pyz)Cl2]. Rietveld analysis of powder XRD suggested that 4 is isostructural to the cobalt analogue 3 ().

elements.content: When crystallization was attempted by mixing solutions A and B, different solids were obtained depending on the metal ions. Except for copper, all the other systems resulted in a clear green solution (Scheme ). After a few weeks, metal complex templated monophasic solids 7−9 crystallized out of this solution. Cobalt and zinc formed isostructural solids, (Hpyz)[{Co(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (7) and (Hpyz)[{Zn(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (8), respectively. In the case of nickel, a novel CP incorporated with an Anderson−Evans cluster, [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2.6H2O (9), was isolated. The reaction with copper under identical conditions resulted in the immediate precipitation of a green colored solid. Rietveld analysis of the powder pattern of the green powder established it to be the 1D CP, [Cu(pyz)Cl2] (5) (). Precipitation of [Cu(pyz)Cl2] is attributed to its low solubility. 5 was filtered off, and the green supernatant liquid was left for crystallization at room temperature. Pink crystals of [Na(CrMo6(OH)8O16)]·10H2O (10) crystallized out after approximately 3 months. When the metal to pyz ratio was increased to 1:3, a new phase(Hpyz)[{Ni(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (11) was obtained only in the case of nickel. Similar reaction with Co and Zn yielded only 7 and 8, respectively.

When the metal to pyz ratio was increased to 1:3, a new phase(Hpyz)[{Ni(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O (11) was obtained only in the case of nickel. Similar reaction with Co and Zn yielded only 7 and 8, respectively.

elements.content: In the solids 7−11, an Anderson−Evans type chromium molybdate cluster is one of the building blocks. The molecular structure of the cluster anion, {CrMo6(OH) x O24−x }(9−x)− is identical to the earlier reports except for the degree of protonation. The structure of the cluster is made of seven edge-sharing octahedra, six of which are {MoO6} octahedra arranged hexagonally around the central {Cr(OH)6} octahedron. The oxygen atoms in the cluster are divided into three kinds according to their coordination: terminal oxygen, doubly bridging oxygen, and central oxygen. Single crystal XRD analysis of the solids 7−9 and 11 revealed that, in addition to the chromium molybdate cluster, a metal pyrazine complex/coordination polymer, {M(pyz)2(H2O)4}2+ (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) or {Ni(pyz)(H2O)5}2+, pyrazinium, acetate, and water molecules were involved in the crystal building (). Crystal structure analysis revealed that 7, 8, and 11 are isostructural; the transition metal atoms were in the octahedral geometry, {M(pyz)2(H2O)2O2/2/}2+, with two nitrogens from two pyrazine moieties, two oxygens from two different Anderson−Evans clusters, and two coordinated water molecules. Each {CrMo6(OH)6O18}3− cluster is covalently linked to a {M(pyz)2(H2O)2}2+ complex through a terminal oxygen atom (O1) extending into the 1D chain, as shown in Figure a. Such 1D chains are formed between an Anderson−Evans cluster and metal octahedra in a few other solids, including 2. Earlier we reported an oxalate bridged copper pyrazole complex covalently linking Anderson−Evans clusters into 1D chains (). The uncoordinated nitrogen of the pyz attached to the metal is involved in H-bonding with the protonated central oxygen atoms of the molybdate cluster, forming a sheet (Figure b). The protonated pyrazine present in 7, 8, and 11 as counter cation shows extensive H-bonding with cluster oxygens. In addition to the two coordinated water molecules attached to the metal, two more water molecules occur per unit cell, strengthening the structure through H-bonding between the metal complex and the cluster oxygens (Figure c). In contrast to the isostructures of cobalt, nickel, and zinc, nickel yielded another solid, [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2·6H2O (9), when the reaction was carried out with lower pyz concentration. In this solid, nickel underwent coordination polymerization, forming the 1D chains of the composition [Ni(pyz)(H2O)4]2+. Nickel is in an octahedral geometry with four water molecules on a plane and two N atoms from two pyrazine molecules along the axial positions. Interestingly, two discrete anions, disordered acetate and an Anderson−Evans cluster, provide charge compensation. The structure also contains six additional water molecules that are involved in H-bonding with water molecules coordinated to nickel forming sheets. The acetate anions are also involved in H-bonding with the water molecules through CH···O interactions (2.545 Å) and with the cluster oxygens (2.625 Å) (Figure ).

elements.content: (a) Each Anderson−Evans type cluster is covalently linked to a discrete {M(pyz)2(H2O)2}2+ (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) complex through corner sharing to form 1D chains in 7, 8, and 11. (b) N···O bonding of pyrazine coordinated to M with a protonated cluster oxygen and a protonated N atom of a free pyrazine moiety with cluster oxygen reveals 2D sheetlike features. (c) Water molecules coordinated to M show H-bonding with cluster oxygens as well as mediating lattice water molecules in 7.

elements.content: Each Anderson−Evans cluster is H-bonded to four 1D coordination polymeric chains of the composition {Ni(pyz)2(H2O)4}2+ in 9. An additional counter anion, an acetate group, is also involved in H-bonding with clusters as well as lattice water.
elements.clean_text: 2  Each Anderson-Evans cluster is H-bonded to four 1D coordination polymeric chains of the composition {Ni(pyz)2(H2O)4}2+ in 9. An additional counter anion, an acetate group, is also involved in H-bonding with clusters as well as lattice water.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 10 is made of an Anderson−Evans type cluster bonded to sodium cations (). Sodium ion is coordinated to six oxygens: two clusters link in a bidentate fashion and two in a monodentate fashion such that each Na is coordinated to four clusters and each cluster is coordinated to four Na atoms, thus forming two-dimensional layers on the ab plane (Figure a). There are only a few examples () wherein the protonation of the cluster differs from the composition {CrMo6(OH)6O18}3−. In one case, it is assigned to water molecules. Terminal oxygen is unlikely to get protonated. The bond-valence calculations showed that the six central oxygen atoms of the Anderson cluster are protonated in 10. BVS is inconclusive about the protonation sites, though O6 is comparatively lower () than other doubly bridged oxygens (O3, 1.879, and O9, 1.865). All the ten water molecules per formula unit present in 10 are found in between the sodium molybdate layers of the composition [Na{CrMo6(OH)8O16}]; they interact among themselves via H-bonding to form chair-like water clusters (2.3−3.56 Å) (Figure b). The corrugated 2D water sheets provide stability to the sodium molybdate sheets. 2 and 10 may be considered as pseudopolymorphs nucleating under two different supramolecular pathways.

elements.content: Crystallization is a supramolecular reaction, and hence, it is critical to identify the molecules that undergo aggregation in the solution followed by condensation during the phase transition to the crystal. Retrosynthesis of the solids reported here as well in the literature (: Table S1 and Figures S4 and S14) reveals the following features: Three pseudopolymorphs of sodium chromium molybdates based on Anderson−Evans cluster 2, 10, and the solid [{Na3(H2O)11}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O () are known. These three solids are built from the Anderson−Evans cluster, sodium hydrate, and water molecules. Retrosynthesis of the three crystal structures suggests that the supramolecular aggregation is dominated by two assembling forces: (i) Alternate assembly of molybdate cluster and sodium hydrate that eventually results in 1D chains. A similar structural feature is noticed in the structures of 7, 8, and 11, where a metal pyrazine hydrate complex replaces sodium hydrate; also, copper pyrazole complexes link Anderson−Evans clusters (). (ii) Aggregation of sodium hydrates to form extended structures. In 2, the counter cations are sodium hydrate chains formed by bridging water molecules. There are several solids in which sodium hydrates aggregate. In 10, the 1D chains are similar to 2 but adjacent chains are linked by another set of sodium hydrate, forming 2D sheets. In contrast to 2 and 10, in the solid [{Na3(H2O)11}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O, adjacent clusters are linked by a trimeric sodium hydrate such that a double chain is formed. Unlike water clustering, aggregation of sodium hydrates into oligomers or low dimensional structures is rarely investigated. In addition to the two assembling forces, coordinated and lattice water also plays a key role in stabilizing a crystal. The number of water molecules present in a solid does not bear any relationship with its structure. In 2, sodium hydrates aggregate and the coordinated water molecules are only involved in nonbonding interaction. In 10, sodium hydrate condenses, with the molybdate cluster forming a sodium molybdate layer and the water in between the layers show an extended noncovalent interaction. As we have discussed in an earlier paper, water aggregation is the result of a cooperative interaction between assembling molecules. The condensing pattern differs depending on the nature of the metal tecton and also on the nature of the crystallizing medium. Our model postulates the supramolecular pathways.
elements.clean_text: Crystallization is a supramolecular reaction, and hence, it is critical to identify the molecules that undergo aggregation in the solution followed by condensation during the phase transition to the crystal. Retrosynthesis of the solids reported here as well in the literature (: Table S1 and Figures S4 and S14) reveals the following features: Three pseudopolymorphs of sodium chromium molybdates based on Anderson-Evans cluster 2, 10, and the solid [{Na3(H2O)11}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O () are known. These three solids are built from the Anderson-Evans cluster, sodium hydrate, and water molecules. Retrosynthesis of the three crystal structures suggests that the supramolecular aggregation is dominated by two assembling forces: (i) Alternate assembly of molybdate cluster and sodium hydrate that eventually results in 1D chains. A similar structural feature is noticed in the structures of 7, 8, and 11, where a metal pyrazine hydrate complex replaces sodium hydrate; also, copper pyrazole complexes link Anderson-Evans clusters (). (ii) Aggregation of sodium hydrates to form extended structures. In 2, the counter cations are sodium hydrate chains formed by bridging water molecules. There are several solids in which sodium hydrates aggregate. In 10, the 1D chains are similar to 2 but adjacent chains are linked by another set of sodium hydrate, forming 2D sheets. In contrast to 2 and 10, in the solid [{Na3(H2O)11}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O, adjacent clusters are linked by a trimeric sodium hydrate such that a double chain is formed. Unlike water clustering, aggregation of sodium hydrates into oligomers or low dimensional structures is rarely investigated. In addition to the two assembling forces, coordinated and lattice water also plays a key role in stabilizing a crystal. The number of water molecules present in a solid does not bear any relationship with its structure. In 2, sodium hydrates aggregate and the coordinated water molecules are only involved in nonbonding interaction. In 10, sodium hydrate condenses, with the molybdate cluster forming a sodium molybdate layer and the water in between the layers show an extended noncovalent interaction. As we have discussed in an earlier paper, water aggregation is the result of a cooperative interaction between assembling molecules. The condensing pattern differs depending on the nature of the metal tecton and also on the nature of the crystallizing medium. Our model postulates the supramolecular pathways.

elements.content: In the case of nickel, the assembly favors 1D CP, suggesting that the 1:1 nickel pyrazine complex (tecton) dominates the solution. Since the chain is cationic, the system chooses the Anderson cluster and acetate as counter anion. In , we have shown another example where cadmium forms a 1D CP with pyridine-3-carboxylic acid and the Anderson−Evans cluster occurs as counter anion. In the case of cobalt and zinc, the formation of a 1:2 metal pyrazine complex (tecton) is responsible for a different supramolecular assembly. Here the chains are anionic and the system could have opted for either sodium hydrate or pyrazinium cations, though the latter is preferred, though pyrazine is less likely to get protonated. We varied the metal to ligand concentration, with an objective to prepare a nickel analogue of 7 and 8 and cobalt and zinc analogues of 9. So far, we have only succeeded in obtaining 11, a nickel analogue of 7 and 8 by increasing the ligand concentration (). In the case of nickel, a lower concentration of pyrazine favored the 1:1 metal pyrazine complex (tecton), and hence, the crystallization of 9 was realized. Low solubility of [Cu(pyz)Cl2] makes it difficult to prepare copper pyrazine templated Anderson cluster based solids. Experiments are underway to crystallize copper based crystals by changing the source of copper salt (nitrate rather than chloride) and varying the concentration of ligand to metal. We are also exploring the condition to form cobalt and zinc CPs incorporating Anderson clusters by choosing a lower concentration of ligand to metal.

elements.content: Measurements of the magnetic susceptibility χ in the range between 300 and 50 K suggest that all materials follow the Curie−Weiss law, χ = C/(T − θ), where C is the Curie constant and θ the Weiss temperature. The values are given in Table . At a simple level, C can be written as C = N A ∑ g i 2 μ B 2 S i ( S i + 1 ) 3 k B where N A is Avogadro’s constant, g i the spectroscopic splitting factor of the ith ion, S i its corresponding spin value, μB the Bohr magneton, and k B Boltzmann’s constant. For Cr3+ (3d3) S = 3/2 and g = 2. Thus, for 8 and 10, one anticipates a C value of 2.12 and 1.80 emu/mol, respectively, in reasonable agreement with measured values. For 7, Co2+ (3d7) in octahedral coordination becomes split by the crystal field into an effective spin S = 1/2 and g ∼ 4.4, yielding an expected C value of 3.69 emu/mol. Tetragonal distortions to the octahedra give rise to an anisotropic g tensor with components g ∥ and g ⊥, yielding an effective value of g 2 = 1/3(g ∥ 2 + 2g ⊥ 2). Since the use of the isotropic g value for Co yields a value of C that is smaller than the measured value, one finds that g ∥ < g ⊥, indicating uniaxial compression of the Co octahedra. For 9 and 11, Ni2+ (3d8), g∼ 2.2, and S = 1, leading to an expected C value of 3.09 and 3.367 emu/mol, respectively, in accord with the experimental results. χM −1 values measured in an applied field of 5 kOe for 7−11 are shown in Figure . Due to the extended separation between the transition metal ions, the interactions are all very weak (Table ), except perhaps for 7, where a detailed low-temperature study of a single crystal may reveal the true nature of the dimensionality of the magnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Measurements of the magnetic susceptibility χ in the range between 300 and 50 K suggest that all materials follow the Curie-Weiss law, χ = C/(T - θ), where C is the Curie constant and θ the Weiss temperature. The values are given in Table . At a simple level, C can be written as  C =     N   A   ∑      g   i     2       μ   B     2     S   i   (   S   i   + 1 )    3   k   B      where N A is Avogadro's constant, g  i  the spectroscopic splitting factor of the ith ion, S  i  its corresponding spin value, μB the Bohr magneton, and k B Boltzmann's constant. For Cr3+ (3d3) S = 3/2 and g = 2. Thus, for 8 and 10, one anticipates a C value of 2.12 and 1.80 emu/mol, respectively, in reasonable agreement with measured values. For 7, Co2+ (3d7) in octahedral coordination becomes split by the crystal field into an effective spin S = 1/2 and g ~ 4.4, yielding an expected C value of 3.69 emu/mol. Tetragonal distortions to the octahedra give rise to an anisotropic g tensor with components g ∥ and g ⊥, yielding an effective value of g 2 = 1/3(g ∥ 2 + 2g ⊥ 2). Since the use of the isotropic g value for Co yields a value of C that is smaller than the measured value, one finds that g ∥  < g ⊥, indicating uniaxial compression of the Co octahedra. For 9 and 11, Ni2+ (3d8), g~ 2.2, and S = 1, leading to an expected C value of 3.09 and 3.367 emu/mol, respectively, in accord with the experimental results. χM -1 values measured in an applied field of 5 kOe for 7-11 are shown in Figure . Due to the extended separation between the transition metal ions, the interactions are all very weak (Table ), except perhaps for 7, where a detailed low-temperature study of a single crystal may reveal the true nature of the dimensionality of the magnetic behavior.

Thermogravimetric analysis of (Hpyz)[{Co(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (7) (Hpyz)[{Zn(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (8) and (Hpyz)[{Ni(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (11) () showed a similar pattern of weight loss. It reveals the loss of water molecules and half a pyrazine molecule in the first step. The next two steps correspond to the loss of the remaining pyrazine moieties. Further weight loss may be attributed to the degradation of Anderson cluster anions. Thermogravimetric analysis of [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2·6H2O (9) showed the weight loss in two steps. The first step corresponds to the loss of coordinated as well as lattice water molecules and acetate molecules. Thermogravimetric analysis of [Na(CrMo6(OH)8O16)]·10H2O (10) reveals the loss of six water molecules in the first step. The next weight loss corresponds to the loss of four water molecules along with a Na atom. Powder XRD of the TGA product of 7−11 shows amorphous character (), indicating that the structure collapses on heating.

Thermal Stability of 7-11 

Thermogravimetric analysis of (Hpyz)[{Co(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O (7) (Hpyz)[{Zn(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O (8) and (Hpyz)[{Ni(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]⋅2H2O (11) () showed a similar pattern of weight loss. It reveals the loss of water molecules and half a pyrazine molecule in the first step. The next two steps correspond to the loss of the remaining pyrazine moieties. Further weight loss may be attributed to the degradation of Anderson cluster anions. Thermogravimetric analysis of [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2⋅6H2O (9) showed the weight loss in two steps. The first step corresponds to the loss of coordinated as well as lattice water molecules and acetate molecules. Thermogravimetric analysis of [Na(CrMo6(OH)8O16)]⋅10H2O (10) reveals the loss of six water molecules in the first step. The next weight loss corresponds to the loss of four water molecules along with a Na atom. Powder XRD of the TGA product of 7-11 shows amorphous character (), indicating that the structure collapses on heating.

elements.content: FTIR spectra of (Hpyz)[{Co(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (7), (Hpyz)[{Zn(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (8), and (Hpyz)[{Ni(pyz)2(H2O)2}{CrMo6(OH)6O18}]·2H2O (11) display similar characteristic patterns of the Anderson-type structure with vibrational bands between 890 and 950 cm−1 for the Mo−Ot bonds, between 650 and 800 cm−1 for the Mo−Ob groups, and between 400 and 600 cm−1 for the Mo−Oc units. The characteristic peaks that range from 1100 to 1600 cm−1 are attributed to the pyrazine ligand. FTIR spectra of [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2·6H2O (9) display similar characteristic patterns of the Anderson-type structure and pyrazine, as observed in 7 and 8. FTIR spectra of [Na(CrMo6(OH)8O16)]·10H2O (10) show similar characteristic patterns of the Anderson-type structure, as observed in 7−9 and 11.

The characteristic peaks that range from 1100 to 1600 cm-1 are attributed to the pyrazine ligand. FTIR spectra of [{Ni(pyz)(H2O)4}2{CrMo6(OH)6O18}](CH3COO)2⋅6H2O (9) display similar characteristic patterns of the Anderson-type structure and pyrazine, as observed in 7 and 8. FTIR spectra of [Na(CrMo6(OH)8O16)]⋅10H2O (10) show similar characteristic patterns of the Anderson-type structure, as observed in 7-9 and 11.

elements.content: Retrosynthetic analysis reported here provides chemical insights into the crystal engineering of metal complex templated Anderson−Evans cluster based solids. The approach enables one to correlate the synthetic protocol with a structure obtained. The results reported here clearly show that metal pyrazine ratio influences the supramolecular aggregation and hence the composition of the solids crystallizing out. However, two factors need to be considered in interpreting the occurrence and absence of these analogues: the rate of formation of a metal pyrazine complex with 1:1 or 1:2 stoichiometry and the solubility of the phase crystallizing out. Low solubility of a solid is probably related to a higher rate of formation of a supramolecular transition state. The intuitive mechanism proposed here will provide us some control over the choice of the reaction variables, such as metal source, ligand, solvent, and temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Retrosynthetic analysis reported here provides chemical insights into the crystal engineering of metal complex templated Anderson-Evans cluster based solids. The approach enables one to correlate the synthetic protocol with a structure obtained. The results reported here clearly show that metal pyrazine ratio influences the supramolecular aggregation and hence the composition of the solids crystallizing out. However, two factors need to be considered in interpreting the occurrence and absence of these analogues: the rate of formation of a metal pyrazine complex with 1:1 or 1:2 stoichiometry and the solubility of the phase crystallizing out. Low solubility of a solid is probably related to a higher rate of formation of a supramolecular transition state. The intuitive mechanism proposed here will provide us some control over the choice of the reaction variables, such as metal source, ligand, solvent, and temperature.

Initially two different aqueous solutions were prepared. The experimental conditions were optimized to enable homogeneity of the solution before and after mixing. Solution A was prepared by adding Na2MoO4·2H2O (2.35 mmol, Merck, 99%) to the solution of CrCl3·6H2O (1.57 mmol, CDH, 99%) in 15 mL of water; this was further acidified with 5 mL of glacial acetic acid. Solution B was prepared by mixing pyrazine (2.52 mmol, Merck, 99%) with the solution of MCl2·xH2O (1.68 mmol, Merck, 99%) (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) in 10 mL of water and 10 mL of methanol. Solution A was then added to solution B with stirring. The resulting clear dark green colored solution was left for crystallization at room temperature. Red block crystals of 7 were obtained after 6 weeks approximately in about 75% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 7: C, 10.35; H, 1.65; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.62; H, 1.74; N, 6.11. Pink block crystals of 8 were obtained after 8 weeks approximately in about 71% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 8: C, 10.30; H, 1.64; N, 6.01. Found: C, 10.41; H, 1.72; N, 6.11. Blue block crystals of 9 were obtained after 4 weeks approximately in about 78% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 9: C, 8.64; H, 2.88; N, 3.36. Found: C, 8.78; H, 2.86; N, 3.69. When M = Cu, as soon as solution A was added to solution B, immediate precipitation occurred. Green precipitate was filtered, washed with acetone, and dried. The remaining filterate was left for crystallization at room temperature. Pink block crystals of 10 were obtained after 12 weeks approximately in about 81% yield (based on Mo).

We also carried out a blank reaction by evaporating solution A without the addition of solution B. Dark green blocklike crystals of 1 were obtained after one month in about 54% yield (based on Mo). The crystals of 1 were filtered, and the supernatant liquid was allowed to evaporate at room temperature; pink blocklike crystals of 2 were obtained after 2 weeks in about 32% yield (based on Mo). In the same way, a blank reaction was carried out on solution B; in all four cases (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn), only powder (3−6) was obtained. When the metal to ligand ratio was increased to 1:3, blue crystals of 11 were obtained after 5 weeks in about 73% yield (based on Mo) in the presence of nickel. Elem. Anal. Calcd for 11: C, 10.36; H, 1.51; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.31; H, 1.48; N, 6.01. In the presence of cobalt and zinc, 7 and 8 were crystallized after 4 and 3 weeks, respectively.

Experimental Section

Synthesis

Initially two different aqueous solutions were prepared. The experimental conditions were optimized to enable homogeneity of the solution before and after mixing. Solution A was prepared by adding Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (2.35 mmol, Merck, 99%) to the solution of CrCl3⋅6H2O (1.57 mmol, CDH, 99%) in 15 mL of water; this was further acidified with 5 mL of glacial acetic acid. Solution B was prepared by mixing pyrazine (2.52 mmol, Merck, 99%) with the solution of MCl2⋅xH2O (1.68 mmol, Merck, 99%) (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) in 10 mL of water and 10 mL of methanol. Solution A was then added to solution B with stirring. The resulting clear dark green colored solution was left for crystallization at room temperature. Red block crystals of 7 were obtained after 6 weeks approximately in about 75% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 7: C, 10.35; H, 1.65; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.62; H, 1.74; N, 6.11. Pink block crystals of 8 were obtained after 8 weeks approximately in about 71% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 8: C, 10.30; H, 1.64; N, 6.01. Found: C, 10.41; H, 1.72; N, 6.11. Blue block crystals of 9 were obtained after 4 weeks approximately in about 78% yield (based on Mo). Elem. Anal. Calcd for 9: C, 8.64; H, 2.88; N, 3.36. Found: C, 8.78; H, 2.86; N, 3.69. When M = Cu, as soon as solution A was added to solution B, immediate precipitation occurred. Green precipitate was filtered, washed with acetone, and dried. The remaining filterate was left for crystallization at room temperature. Pink block crystals of 10 were obtained after 12 weeks approximately in about 81% yield (based on Mo).

We also carried out a blank reaction by evaporating solution A without the addition of solution B. Dark green blocklike crystals of 1 were obtained after one month in about 54% yield (based on Mo). The crystals of 1 were filtered, and the supernatant liquid was allowed to evaporate at room temperature; pink blocklike crystals of 2 were obtained after 2 weeks in about 32% yield (based on Mo). In the same way, a blank reaction was carried out on solution B; in all four cases (M = Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn), only powder (3-6) was obtained. When the metal to ligand ratio was increased to 1:3, blue crystals of 11 were obtained after 5 weeks in about 73% yield (based on Mo) in the presence of nickel. Elem. Anal. Calcd for 11: C, 10.36; H, 1.51; N, 6.04. Found: C, 10.31; H, 1.48; N, 6.01. In the presence of cobalt and zinc, 7 and 8 were crystallized after 4 and 3 weeks, respectively.

<caption>
<title>Experimental Procedure for the Crystallization of Chromium Molybdate Anion, [CrMo<sub>6</sub>O<sub>24</sub>]<sup>
<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>−</sup>, Based Solids from Aqueous Solution Containing Metal Pyrazine Complex</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2010-00754k_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Experimental Procedure for the Crystallization of Chromium Molybdate Anion, [CrMo6O24] n-, Based Solids from Aqueous Solution Containing Metal Pyrazine Complex

cln_elements.content: (a) Each Anderson−Evans type cluster is covalently linked to a discrete {M(pyz)2(H2O)2}2+ (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) complex through corner sharing to form 1D chains in 7, 8, and 11. (b) N···O bonding of pyrazine coordinated to M with a protonated cluster oxygen and a protonated N atom of a free pyrazine moiety with cluster oxygen reveals 2D sheetlike features. (c) Water molecules coordinated to M show H-bonding with cluster oxygens as well as mediating lattice water molecules in 7.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Each Anderson-Evans type cluster is covalently linked to a discrete {M(pyz)2(H2O)2}2+ (M = Co, Ni, and Zn) complex through corner sharing to form 1D chains in 7, 8, and 11. (b) N⋅⋅⋅O bonding of pyrazine coordinated to M with a protonated cluster oxygen and a protonated N atom of a free pyrazine moiety with cluster oxygen reveals 2D sheetlike features. (c) Water molecules coordinated to M show H-bonding with cluster oxygens as well as mediating lattice water molecules in 7.

cln_elements.content: Each Anderson−Evans cluster is H-bonded to four 1D coordination polymeric chains of the composition {Ni(pyz)2(H2O)4}2+ in 9. An additional counter anion, an acetate group, is also involved in H-bonding with clusters as well as lattice water.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Each Anderson-Evans cluster is H-bonded to four 1D coordination polymeric chains of the composition {Ni(pyz)2(H2O)4}2+ in 9. An additional counter anion, an acetate group, is also involved in H-bonding with clusters as well as lattice water.

cln_elements.content: (a) The Anderson−Evans clusters are linked through sodium cations to form a 2D sheet in 10. (b) A chair-type decameric water cluster occurs between sodium chromium molybdate sheets. (c) Decameric water clusters interact, forming an unusual 2D sheet in 10. (d) Space filling model of the packing in 10. Water sheet (shown in orange) holding the two [Na{CrMo6(OH)8O16}] sheets (shown in red and blue) in 10.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The Anderson-Evans clusters are linked through sodium cations to form a 2D sheet in 10. (b) A chair-type decameric water cluster occurs between sodium chromium molybdate sheets. (c) Decameric water clusters interact, forming an unusual 2D sheet in 10. (d) Space filling model of the packing in 10. Water sheet (shown in orange) holding the two [Na{CrMo6(OH)8O16}] sheets (shown in red and blue) in 10.

cln_elements.content: χM −1 versus T plot for 7−11.

metadata.title: Crystallization of Anderson−Evans Type Chromium Molybdate Solids Incorporated with a Metal Pyrazine Complex or Coordination Polymer
